qas.question: How many species of polychaetes have known lifecycles?
What percent of polychaetes produce yolk-rich eggs?
What is the benefit of yolk-rich eggs?

answers.text: reduce the time the larva needs to spend among the plankton

qas.question: What are most polychaetes' eggs covered in?
How many species of polychaetes have impossible lifecycles?
What percent of polychaetes produce milk?

plausible_answers.text: reduce the time the larva needs to spend among the plankton

qas.question: What is the benefit of rotten eggs?
What are all polychaetes' eggs covered in?

context: However, the lifecycles of most living polychaetes, which are almost all marine animals, are unknown, and only <a0_0><b4_0>about 25%<b4_0/><a0_0/> of the 300+ species whose lifecycles are known follow this pattern. About <a1_0><b5_0>14%<b5_0/><a1_0/> use a similar external fertilization but produce yolk-rich eggs, which <a2_0><b6_0>reduce the time the larva needs to spend among the plankton<b6_0/><a2_0/>, or eggs from which miniature adults emerge rather than larvae. The rest care for the fertilized eggs until they hatch – some by producing <a3_0><b7_0>jelly<b7_0/><a3_0/>-covered masses of eggs which they tend, some by attaching the eggs to their bodies and a few species by keeping the eggs within their bodies until they hatch. These species use a variety of methods for sperm transfer; for example, in some the females collect sperm released into the water, while in others the males have a penis that inject sperm into the female. There is no guarantee that this is a representative sample of polychaetes' reproductive patterns, and it simply reflects scientists' current knowledge.
